Title: üñº A military court in St. Petersburg sentenced a Ukrainian to 15...
Description: A military court in St. Petersburg sentenced a Ukrainian to 15 years for arson of a military registration and enlistment office1 The Western District Military Court in St. Petersburg sentenced Pyotr Romanyuk, a native of Ukraine, to 15 years in prison for attempting to arson a military registration and enlistment office in the Karelian city of Suoyarvi, reports the Karelian publication From Karelia with freedom.Romanyuk was found guilty under Article 205 of the Criminal Code of the Russian Federation (-Terrorist attack-). He was sentenced to 15 years in prison with the first four years to be served in prison and the rest of the term in a maximum security colony. The defense said it would appeal the verdict.The arson attempt occurred on the night of May 12 last year, when an unknown person threw a Molotov cocktail into the military registration and enlistment office building. The fire went out and the man fled the scene. Security discovered traces of the attack only in the morning. A few days later, Romanyuk was detained on suspicion of arson.After the arrest, Russian authorities added Romanyuk to the list of terrorists and extremists.The trial took place in St. Petersburg, and Romanyuk himself participated in the trial via video link from Petrozavodsk. The defense argued that the examination of surveillance video, which allegedly proved his involvement in the arson, was carried out with violations.

After the sentence - eight years of strict regime - he was transported to Ufa, and then to a correctional colony in Dimitrovgrad, where his death was reported.

Title: üñº - Dismantling of the Kyiv regime - Russia can propose at negot...
Description: -Dismantling the Kyiv regime- can be proposed by Russia at the negotiations, - The Washington Post-An influential Moscow think tank, closely associated with the Russian FSB,- has prepared a document with maximalist demands aimed at achieving Moscow‚Äôs strategic goals in the Ukrainian conflict, writes The Washington Post. According to the publication, the document was prepared in February, a week before the negotiations between Russia and the USA, held on February 18 in Riyadh in Saudi Arabia.According to information received by journalists from European intelligence sources, the document proposals from the administration of US President Donald Trump to end the war in Ukraine within 100 days, as well as plans to send peacekeepers to the region, are rejected. Instead, it is argued that -a peaceful resolution of the Ukrainian crisis cannot occur until 2026.-The authors of the document insist on official recognition of Russian sovereignty over the occupied territories of Ukraine. In addition, it is proposed to create a buffer zone in the north-east of Ukraine, adjacent to the Bryansk and Belgorod regions of Russia, as well as a demilitarized zone in the south of Ukraine, which will also affect the Odessa region.The document also contains a demand for the -complete dismantling- of the current Ukrainian government, since the authors believe that -the current Kiev regime cannot be changed from within the country.- In addition, there is disagreement with maintaining the size of the Ukrainian army at the current level and with the continued supply of American weapons to Ukraine after a possible peace agreement.The document emphasizes the need to normalize relations between Washington and Moscow by restoring the full diplomatic staff of embassies. It is proposed to appoint Alexander Darchiev as Ambassador of the Russian Federation to the United States, which, according to the authors, should help improve bilateral relations.As for the sanctions imposed against Russia, the authors of the document believe that their significance is -clearly exaggerated- and reject attempts to involve Russia in a peace agreement through partial lifting of sanctions. They argue that -it is unclear what Russia would benefit from- such an approach.Russian Presidential spokesman Dmitry Peskov told The Washington Post that the Kremlin was -not aware of such recommendations- and called them -extremely contradictory.- -We are working with more thoughtful options,- said Peskov.At the same time, as the publication notes, some of the proposals presented in the document have already been put forward by the Russian authorities. In particular, Russia offered the US access to its mineral resources, including in the occupied territories of Ukraine, and also advocated for the restoration of the staff of diplomats in the embassies of the two countries. Description: Russian arrested after ship collision in North SeaThe container ship Solong, which collided with the oil tanker Stena Immaculate in the North Sea on March 10, was driven by a 59-year-old Russian citizen. Tsarev survived.Tsarev was a deputy of the Verkhovna Rada from 2002 to 2014. After the start of the war in Donbass, he went over to the side of the separatists and became the speaker of the -parliament of Novorossiya-. Description: Former President of the Philippines was detained on an ICC warrantFormer President of the Philippines, 79-year-old Rodrigo Duterte, was detained at Manila International Airport on a warrant from the International Criminal Court (ICC). The arrest is related to charges of crimes against humanity committed during his anti-drug campaign, reports the Associated Press. According to human rights activists, more than 12 thousand people were killed in anti-drug operations during Duterte's presidency from 2016 to 2022. In 2019, Duterte removed the Philippines from the jurisdiction of the Rome Statute, under which the ICC operates, so Duterte's lawyer, Salvador Panelo, called the arrest illegal. However, the court stated that it had jurisdiction over crimes committed up to that point - from November 1, 2011 to March 16, 2019 inclusive. The detainee's daughter, Sara Duterte, is the vice president of the Philippines. President Ferdinand Marcos Jr., who succeeded Duterte as president in 2022, has stated his readiness to cooperate with the ICC on issues related to the arrest. It is currently unknown where Duterte is being held after his arrest and when he will be brought to Europe to be transferred to the ICC.
